comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Ancient Egyptian Art, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi Hans!  Done and many thanks for all your recent shots added to our Brooklyn Museum group - looks like you had a great visit to our Egypt Reborn exhibition :) -shelley, manager of information systems, brooklyn museum

comment.author: 21713679@N05
comment._content: Thanks for the display, reminds me of my Art History classes at Valley College, Van Nuys, CA. early 1970's. I lucked out getting the professor I had, she showed us 45 minutes of these shots everyday for 3 years, she had. She said she had been everywhere except N. Vietnam & China and was going my last year there. I used to ask her at the end of the class, " how many people lived in those days and were they all artists " ? She always had her 80+ friend sitting near the artifact. She said these stones weighed about 86 tons and somehow they were put on top of the vert. ones. Amazing, Special, I wonder who got her photos? Thank You.

comment.author: 7573205@N06
comment._content: Hello Shelly, You are welcome. Indeed, I enjoy every visit to the Brooklyn Museum. Like so many other important museums in the world (Louvre, Metropolitan Museum etc) your great museum allows taking pictures. Visitors feel happy when they can take their camera inside the museum, and they can tell so much more to other people how fantastic this museum is by showing their pictures (of course all made without flash!). Every time I visit the States I try to visit the Brooklyn Museum. A small enigma remains. During my most recent visit in 2007 I hoped to see the spectacular statue of Amenhotep III (also called Amenophis III). But it was not there. I wondered what happened with it. I hope that this greatest treasure of your museum will come back in the permanent collection of the Brooklyn Museum. If not, why? I was realy a little bit disappointed. Here is the photo that I made of the statue in the year 2000. Thanks for your comments and lots of gratitude to the Brooklyn Museum. Hans Head of a good-looking pharaoh Amenophis III (Amenhotep III). In this over life-sized interpretation we see him wearing the blue crown.

comment.author: 9117864@N06
comment._content: Tantas cosas leídas sobre las pirámides egipcias parecen ser imaginarias o de ensueño, pero nombres de sitios, descubridores, antropólogos o características de los restos arqueológicos se vuelven una realidad al ver estas imágenes y afirman nuestros conocimientos . Resulta un placer disfrutar en la intimidad de estas vistas hurgando en los detalles; lo conocido por lo escrito se vuelve realidad con estas imágenes convirtiendose en algo que de verdad era cierto. Nuestra gratitud al Brooklyn Museum
